channel.title: New local problems on FixMyStreet

item.title: Pothole at the stop line, on the right turn lane from Danson Road., 30th January
item.description:
Large pothole on Danson Road, in the offside lane, close to the traffic signal stop line at Crook Log. This is dangerous for cyclists and motorcycle riders and could also cause damage to vehicles.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Danson Road, Blendon, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Pothole in new road suface, 30th January
item.description:
Because the newly laid road surface was installed without adding drainage, water pools on the north bound carriageway, running-off the woods. This has now caused a new pothole in the newly laid road surface. This is dangersous in the wet and dark as it cannot be easily seen by cyclists or motorbikes.
Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Burcharbro Road, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Drain has sunk creating a large pothole, 30th January
item.description:

item.title: Silver birch tree outside 11 Evangelist Road, 30th January
item.description:
This tree is causing subsidence damage to the front of no.13 Evangelist Road. Site investigations have been carried out and betula roots have been discovered beneath the foundations within the shrinkable clay subsoil
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 2, Evangelist Road, Kentish Town, Greater London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Fridge and many bags of rubbish dumped near public pathway., 30th January
item.description:
Someone dumped a fridge near the public pathway and also many bags of rubbish outside the bin storage area of the house in Pier Way (oppositea block of flats). The bags of rubbish were split open and spilling onto the public pathway - food and other rubbish causing people to slip over. It was also creating a public health hazard (foxes and rats). My neighbour and I cleared the rubbish, but the fridge still needs to be removed. It's been there for 2 days. Is it possible to determine who the perpetrator is?

Nearest address to the pin placed on the map (from OS Places API): Pier Way, Thamesmead
Report on FixMyStreet
